text: Nietzsche talked about perceived scarcity... Perceived, reason for war between two tribes on a resource rich plain.

replies.author: @NeatSquash
replies.text: As Thomas Sowell would mention, 'there is always an "unmet need"'.

replies.author: @samplexample
replies.text:
Neitzsche was wrong. 

Resources are limited. 
Human need/want is infinite.

replies.author: @VoxTenebres
replies.text:
@samplexample 
"Needs" are measurable and finite. The amount of food you need, the amount of sleep you need, the amount of warm and water you need, these are all measurable and mainly scale with the amount of people. 

"Want" being infinite - is entirely Nietzsche's point

Even surrounded by abundance they are fighting over the _perceived_ scarcity, they're not fighting for food or water.

replies.author: @ekscalybur
replies.text: @VoxTenebres Even if you are surrounded by abundance, you still know it's finite. So the tribe on the other end of the valley is still in competition with your tribe. Competition in the game of survival is still a threat, the scarcity is real.

author: @schuylergeery-zink1923
text:
It seems to me that if you are given everything, that doesn‚Äôt make you less selfish. If anything it makes you more so either entitled or by noticing the scarcity and hoarding what you are given. But if you scrap hard for everything you have and now have your needs met with abundance, you become more generous because you‚Äôve been there and want to help lift others up to where you now are. It‚Äôs not a zero-sum game when you become successful, but it is when you have nothing. Capitalism allows your true nature to flourish bc you can make money off of your passion. The state probably doesn‚Äôt care about the songs I play or the books I write unless it‚Äôs propaganda, so art has no place in a Marxist society, especially not politically critical art. Whereas art flourishes in a capitalist society because people will pay for it as they like it and encourage artists. 

Finally, all individuals can work collectively together but the collective can never work individually. That‚Äôs the nail in the coffin of Marxism. Individuals in a capitalist society can actually be more or less Marxist on a self-sufficient farm. But individuals cannot operate safely in a collectivist society. Even worse, we see evidence that capitalism persists under Marxism in the black market bc people are attracted to efficient answers for their problem and freedom to make choices. But the state clearly would rather enslave us and force our hand.

replies.author: @16m49x3
replies.text:
I'd say people are rather selfish. There's the notion that any action you do can always be boiled down to a selfish one. It might be a hyperbole, but it's not wrong.
If you reach a point where you have superfluous wealth, even if you share it with others, you are still doing that because you value the companionship, the social credit, the moral developments, or the progress that money brings. It's still a transaction to a fundamentally selfish goal. 

Just like when Gates spend his own money to fight world hunger, he does so through his own moral code and would call himself good for doing so. However pushing his own morals on the world is still selfish, and to someone with different morals, the consequences of this spending of wealth can seem downright sinister.

Giving your own world view a bigger place in the world is a selfish goal, and to many that can be more important than a bigger house or a 2nd car.

How one gets his/her wealth is of course something that should be examined. If it is gained immorally, then restitution should be made.
But to assume that simply HAVING that wealth is immoral, regardless of how it is acquired--or that there is no moral pathway to wealth beyond a certain amount, is so utterly asinine as to not even merit a response. It's a waste of time to even have a dialogue with socialists/communists. If they make demands of you, ignore them. If they attack you, defend yourself. It's that simple.

author: @Heartdrive
text: Marx is wrong about scarcity and selfishness. Its what people assign value to, that they are selfish with. Something could be in abundance but people will be selfish with it because theyve assigned it to be of great value to them. For instance your late father gave you a coin thats not worth anything but its something that reminds you of him. Youre going to be very selfish with that coin and trust very few with it even if it were to greatly help someone else. Where as on the opposite side to that, some parents will go without food to feed their own children even if it means they are hurting themselves.

author: @jendoe9436
text:
Main rule in basic Economic theory: Assume people are rational. From there, one can theorize which option a person will take cause the assumption is they will choose the most good for them. 
Main rule in reality: People are not rational. None of the fancy graphs and formulas will ever fully capture human behavior. 

Honestly, Economics was one of my favorite subjects, especially when we got into Game Theory. Prisoner‚Äôs Dilemma is a good example of people trying to figure out what is the best outcome from a poor pool. 
I find the idea of ‚ÄòStrong Pig, Weak Pig‚Äô or ‚ÄòBig Pig, Little Pig/Piglet‚Äô also an interesting take. Pretty much there‚Äôs two pigs, one bigger than the other, in an area where a lever needs to be pressed to distribute food on the other end. If both do nothing, neither eat so no one benefits. If BP presses the lever, then Piglet gets first dibs while BP will push them aside for the remaining food when it gets there. If Piglet presses the lever, the BP will probably eat all the food before Piglet has the chance to eat. If both press it, then Piglet will have to get to the food first for a chance to eat before BP makes it. If Piglet is too slow, then they wasted energy for negative to zero gain. Most graphs I‚Äôve seen have Piglet gaining something under the assumption they‚Äôll be faster than BP, but if it‚Äôs Weak Pig then that might make a more pronounced difference based off its nature.
The argument then gets down to which option benefits both. From Piglet‚Äôs standpoint, it‚Äôs obviously better if BP presses the lever so they can eat. From BP‚Äôs standpoint, the lever needs to be pushed and whether they push it or will affect how much BP can eat, though not as drastic as in Piglet‚Äôs case. 
So make the stronger provide the means, let the weak get first dibs, and then push them aside so the stronger can get something? Let the weak provide the means, and the strong collect all the gains without giving to the weak? Or both start at the same place and the spoils go to whoever gets there first? 

The more moral answer seems to let the weak benefit and then the strong will get their due. But shouldn‚Äôt the strong be the first entitled to the product of their labor? 
Issue with weak pressing the lever is they may never get the benefits, but the strong were able to continue on. If both contributed and started from the same place, then isn‚Äôt only fair that the best got the most reward? 

Sorry for the seemingly random topic. I just tend to geek out whenever Game Theory is brought up.

author: @427Arbok
text:
I can't believe I'm steelmanning Marx, but I think the point about selfishness and scarcity was probably meant as follows: that selfishness is a behavior caused by scarcity and not a fundamental aspect of human nature.  

It isn't entirely out-of-the-question, as selfish behavior is a fairly logical response to scarcity‚Äîwhereas it might be more logical to share and help others in times of plenty because that good deed might be repaid some day.  Of course, tha explanation still indicates that humans are, by nature, self-interested, which I don't think is what Marx was going for (despite seeming to be the most true probability).  This also does, however, bring-up the rather interesting point that selfish behavior can sometimes go against an individual's self-interest, particularly in regards to interactions with others.

author: @captainphoenix
text: I don't know that Josh quite understands the economic concept of "scarcity". I think he's stuck working in the contextual framework of the dictionary definition, which is not the same as the economic definition. Scarcity is endemic to the human condition, which means you would have to change the underlying human condition _first_ before you could "eliminate" scarcity. Which means that simply eliminating "scarcity" (dictionary definition) both won't actually eliminate "scarcity" (economic definition) and won't affect the human condition, because the human condition is the independent variable in this relationship, not the dependent variable. In fact, in TNG, the reason we consider this a "post-scarcity world" isn't just the technological advancements, but also the fact that humans _themselves_ have fundamentally changed, which is why no one does things for "money" any more, and everyone simply does things for "fulfillment". Sargon was right to label Roddenberry's hypothetical world "extremely optimistic".

author: @annbrown3037
text:
Human beings are selfish/self interested.  It is a biological imperative which has brought us to where we are now.
As our brains grew we learned, and over time we came to understand that, for a miriad of reasons, it is in our own self interest to cooperate with those around us - safety in numbers, reciprocal food sharing...we learn as toddlers that cooperation and sharing ends up getting you more in terms of material things, but also in terms of alliances and human connections.
Some of our behaviours are adaptive and apparently altruistic...giving aid to strangers for example.  Aside from the feelings of wellbeing this can bring, it also signals status as a generous person - something people may remember when you are in need.
Also, it is ameliorating the suffering you see around you, which ultimately makes for a more settled and less threatening environment for yourself and your progeny thereby increasing probability for success.
We are not unselfish.  We have learned how to compete and cooperate with one another to the greatest benefit for the most people.

When that breaks down - as history shows us - our real selves emerge.  And it ain't pretty.

author: @Nudhul
text: I think the buy low avoid high phenomenon with monkeys isn't all that surprising. Any animal that scavenges and stores food, like squirrels, will expend a greater amount of energy when gathering when food is abundant rather than when it's scarce. Spending time and energy looking for food when it's not widely available is a waste of banked resources that may end up earning no gain or a net loss, when it could be spent in other activities such as nest building or searching for mating partners. I believe this instinctual understanding of energy investment against payoff is a large contributor to behavioral patterns of animal species.

author: @pumplepee
text: People crave things that have been both useful and scarce throughout our evolutionary history. Eliminating scarcity won't eliminate cravings, such a thing would probably require hundreds of thousands of years of evolution in a scarcity-free environment. Here's an example of something that is very scarce in the wild but plentiful in our modern societies: sugar. And despite its abundance, people still crave it to such an extent that health issues related to its excessive consumption are now the major cause of death in developed countries. You can't eliminate such a deeply rooted behaviour by just snapping your fingers.

author: @thomaskilroy3199
text:
Am I crazy or does the prisoner‚Äôs dilemma single-handedly make the case against Marx that cooperation has a benefit to it even in a scarcity society?

You guys mentioned that it vindicates cooperation ‚Äòover a long period of time‚Äô but I feel like you brushed over the significance of it.

The square shows clearly that the only way one prisoner gets off scott-free is if the other prisoner does *not* make the same simple calculation that they do. 
Whereas if each prisoner musters the basic awareness that the other prisoner is approximately as smart as them and in roughly the same scenario, they would each know that should they sell each other out they will both be worse off, they will know that acting selfishly, despite being the ‚Äòrational‚Äô option when going in blind, is in fact the worse strategy if both of them do it.

The gradient between the ‚Äò1 year each for silence‚Äô and the ‚Äò2 years each for ratting‚Äô, as emerges visibly to each prisoner assuming they know about each other, is THE gradient that trust overcomes, the difference between the 2 years and the 1 year is the fundamental unit value of trust to the selfish gene.

The only prerequisite for trust to become a value of rational self-interest is an understanding of the other person as ‚Äòlike me‚Äô, which is fundamentally the revelation that the social domain exists in the first place. 
So the very fact that Marx and other humans can consider selfishness as ‚Äòproblematic‚Äô indicates that humans are typically aware of this higher-order rational, therefore humans on roughly even terms can trust each other.
The only reason people don‚Äôt trust each other is when they cannot trust that their circumstances roughly match, when the other person is visibly different and strange.
The original prisoner‚Äôs dilemma, where the prisoners are not aware of each other, is set among prisoners because it is fundamentally the rationale dilemma of an anti-social person, not a pro-social person. 
Indeed it is the psychopath‚Äôs dilemma that sees them run out of town as soon as they are discovered as Jordan Peterson is fond of referencing.

The fact that Marx does not bestow this trust upon humanity at the fundamental level, to my mind merely betrays the fact that he thinks himself too different from the normal person to trust them. 
Only a very arrogant or very self-hating person fears that they can fundamentally not honestly and cooperatively present themselves to humanity and benefit from doing so.

author: @mcalsip
text: I agree that capitalism is inherent to human nature. The very first tenet of capitalism is that the worker is entitled to the fruits of their labor. The hunter that collects the game, owns the game. The craftsman who builds the furniture, owns the furniture and is entitled to sell it at a price the market will bear. And in a modern sense, the factory worker owns their time and is free to sell it to the factory owner at an hourly rate at a price that the market will bear.

author: @clintonknight9798
text: The Predator / Prey relationship isn't simply about consumption either. The predator consumes, typically, the weakest available prey. The slow, the feeble, the incapable of defense. This means less risk to the predator, which means there is some logic to the "market" of consumption. The same is said to the biological drive to make things less risk averse, and maximum gains of available.

Scarcity is a product of demand vs supply. It does not matter how plentiful something is, if the demand is greater, then the product is scarce and people are selfish. One only has to look at the toilet role event horizon that appeared in March 2020.

The west suffers from selfishness to quite a staggering degree, not because pesto sauce is limited, but that the social status that dictates you should have pesto for lunch is scarce. In a world of plenty, people will just want something else.

The other question is, is selfishness actually a bad thing?

author: @marcuslewitzki4610
text:
Scarcity has been the reality for life since its dawn so evolution has thus favoured self preservation which is the foundation of what we broadly call "selfishness". Even if scarcity is eliminated you cannot socially engineer away our human nature. You can only create a system that accomodates it and tries to meet our needs while taking our sometimes destructive traits into account and create a culture with rules/laws that to the best of our knowledge tries to prevent and deal with their negative consequences.

I don't think most communists shares Marx's view on selfishness, I think they very much believe it to be part of human nature but it's something THEY can rid humanity from by creating a system that dogmatically doesn't allow it in any form - a totalitarian collective. The individuals simply cannot be allowed to live for themselves but for "the greater good", for the collective. It's basically a cult ideology which at its core is based on contempt for human nature and the concept of the indiviudual. Obviously, if "selfishness" is part of our nature "the greater good" must accomodate for this. You simply cannot say that the elimination of a fundamental human trait is for "the greater good" when the collective consists of individuals who all share this trait. It's an inherent contradiction in communism and that's why it has ALWAYS failed miserably and will continue to do so forever.

author: @scottmc2626
text:
I doubt the notion that a post scarcity society os possible. If gold and diamonds were relegated only to their inherent utility, as opposed to their subjective value, they would not be scarce since there would always be more supply than need. It is only the subjective value of being shiny and enduring that elevates demand beyond utilistic necessity. 

Human nature makes them scarce. Therefore, if there is no scarcity in food, drink, shelter, clothing, transportation, etc., human nature will always find something  it can make scarce for the purpose of driving its value up. Bitcoin is one example.

author: @chrisbingley
text:
I would disagree that humanity is a selfish species. We're a competitive species. We want to be better than everybody, everything, else. This is why we have entire industries based on competition (sports, E-sports, etc). 

If we were a selfish species, we wouldn't have co-operated to the point that we could create civilisations, or live in some of the most inhospitable regions of the planet.

replies.author: @Lttlemoi
replies.text:
Selfishness can act in different degrees on different levels of organization. e.g. the members of tribe A will be selfish as a whole towards tribe B because they are different tribes. Within tribe A, you have selfishness between different families and between members of a family. Externally, tribes A and B may cooperate whenever required in order to deprive tribe C of contested resources, because C is seen to have a more dissimilar culture compared to either A and B, than the dissimilarity between A and B. At all levels, from the individual to families, tribes, cultural groups and up to the top-most possible level of organization, you have both selfishness and cooperation at play.
Replace tribes with cities, states, nations and supra-national organizations and the description still holds for the current day as well as it held thousands of years ago.

author: @DrachonaTheWolf
text: Scarcity is universally present, and I mean that in every sense of the word "universal". Technically, the Earth and the Sun are limited resources, but even on a smaller scale, fresh water, clean air, and nutritious food are limited. Arguably, getting rid of capitalism would dramatically increase scarcity, not eliminate it, because suddenly you can't pay to have resources shipped to you which are otherwise nonexistent in your area. Anyone who thinks that selfishness is a product of capitalism has no understanding of reality. I think they would benefit significantly from living in the wild for a short period of time. Wait until you and another predator are fighting for a source of food, and then see if you still think all scarcity is artificial and selfishness is unnatural.

And the summarization of Marx's theories on the individual and society are abhorent. He was a failed thinker and lawyer who didnt understand why the average man was. Thanks again for this breakdown.

author: @bfranciscop
text: Re selfishness and scarcity: Economics already describes this with the demand curve, in a FAR more useful and precise way than Marx's ridiculous theories. When things are not scarce, people don't suddenly become less selfish, it's just that non scarce goods are cheap. People will still act selfishly, but scarce goods are just more expensive. Price is merely our way of prioritizing how generous we want to be with things.

author: @clintonknight9798
text:
Think of Marx's belief on the individual being a mouth piece of society, more like all individuals represent the net sum of the community. Without all voices collectively we can not express the full range of society. Without the full range of society we are but the minimum of exposed views. 

If we compare this to the nature of morality versus selfishness we assume that scarcity allows us to regulate our needs only in the assumption that was can not gather all resources. In short, we are not capable of individually creating a monopoly. The ability to do so would take more effort than the individual. This is not to say that Marx was correct. The individual can indeed go against the categorical imperative and use the efforts of others in order to extend the desire of the individual.

author: @unncommonsense
text: Germans and collectivism. What the hell is wrong with them.

author: @clintonknight9798
text:
The capitalist is not inherently selfish. The capitalist goal is to bring to market, not consume. The consumption means simply eating your product. Consumption does not make the individual capable or interacting in the market. So it is only the expansion of bringing to market that the capitalist flourishes. The extreme of this would be the over reduction of resources from source. The conservationist would argue that the regular manufacture and steady replenishment of resources means you must also protect your supply that you bring to market. 

A lack of understanding of the scarcity or its limits makes the capitalist respond with only the assumption I must bring to market as much as I can while I can control the market. If it is a truly free market, there is not control. With as much, you can not have control.

author: @tkitsz
text:
Consciousness does not appose nature. In fact it is simply a brain function that has evolved naturally. Not every conscious animal is rational, so that thought process is wrong. 
Another thing is that selfishness is often counter productive, especially in herd animals (witch humans still are, despite the fact that most of us see us as more than animals, witch we are essentially not). Doing what is best for the group, is very often what is best for the individual as well. It is the main reason why animals that live in groups develop that ability for empathy. And empathy is not a rational thing, it's based on emotion. Though that does not mean you cannot rationalize it. 

Rationality can and is very often used to legitimize selfishness. Sociopaths often think it is their duty, or at least not their fault that they fool people, and manipulate them. To them it teaches those individuals that they shouldnt be so gullible. They rationalize their own horrible behavior to justify it. There is 0 empathy, while fully aware of the entire situation and their own selfish actions and the consequences of the actions. In fact it is the very negative outcome for the other person that is the pre planned goal of the sociopath. 

Simply put there are logical reasons to be found for both being selfless or selfish. So the statement that through rationality you can overcome selfishness is factually untrue. Proven by the fact that us humans have been rational since the enlightenment at least (actually way long before that, the very idea of a god is an attempt at rationalizing natural events that they didn't fully understand yet). But still wars are being fought, resources hoarded, people left to die from hunger and preventable deceases and other countless atrocities that are being done on a daily basis. Often pre planned, and knowing that other people will be negatively effected. China's government consciously makes decisions based on their own rationale and ideas, that negatively impacts their citizen for the sole improvement of their own selfish interests.

Personally I have never read Cant, but I can safely say he was wrong. Otherwise China and other evil regimes would not excist. Unless you want to argue that these regimes do not use rationality at all, and are purely random actions, devoid of consciousness thought and rationality.

author: @anthonywarwick
text:
These two are not equipped to analyse this topic.
They are approaching this with top-down analysis and when you're dealing with topics such as self-awareness of the individual and decision making you simply cannot discount the fine details since they set up the underlying field of action.

For example the word rational is used with respect to Immanuel Kant's work, but what does rational mean? For rational to be well-defined we would need to have a complete classification of what is considered irrational and we don't have that either. Josh's subscription to Kantian ideals also shows a naivety to the incompleteness of Kant's models.
Kant is completely ignorant of the mechanisms of Irreducible Representation.
If we are ignorant of the consequences of Irreducibility of word/symbol problems then we cannot form a particularly coherent image of "thought" since we must represent thought through symbols.
Given that there are completely irreducible symbolic representations (i.e. while I may be able to express the meaning of this post in fewer words, the existence of an irreducible ordering of symbols is a requirement for ANY post else all words collapse and there can be no meaning), we can only reasonably conclude that while the network structure of our brain may be somewhat plastic it is indeed restricted within a fixed limit that we cannot "think ourselves out of" [this can be explained through algebraic structures associated to the graph/network, see Leavitt path algebras or C* algebras i.e. what Josh mentioned as the sort of "two brain" hypothesis falls into a specific subset of a path algebra, we may expand this hypothesis into domain specific decision making as well by considering how non-trivial ideals within the network can form coherent sub-algebras then start considering how the sums of partial isomorphisms form an overall decision making structure, this then falls into a class of non-IBN ring algebras and we must work within not necessarily linearly causal logical frameworks].
Within this framework we may then consider how individual selfishness maps to collective social benefit. Individuals who act completely selfishly do not have access to the level of domain specificity that a social collective has.
The sole individual must do everything as opposed to being able to focus on a singular field to produce more efficient results within a social system.
There is very explicitly a selfish reason to be social. This selfish reason very explicitly fits into theories of natural selection because when a pressure is introduced to an ecosystem the sole individuals have less access to resources and are then less likely to survive.
Both of these outcomes are due to selfishness but they aren't necessarily comparable in terms of something like a "selfishness index" where one party is more or less selfish than the other, they are simply oriented along different vectors where one of them fails to predominate under the action of the underlying field.
The reason they orient along different vectors can then be due to any number of underlying local constraints on individuals including but not limited to scarcity of resources making sole competition more preferable, lack of socialisation meaning that an individual may be unable to access the other option, geographic isolation, etc. We notice here that the local constraints and global constraints to not necessarily operate within a necessarily linearly causal frame rather that the global constraints emerge due to interactions of local constraints resulting in a structure that appears to be representable as a non-IBN ring algebra since we have "interactions across dimensions". {Global system and local system are different dimensions, the concept of "spatial dimension" is a part of this broader mathematical kind of dimension.}

Not properly defining what we mean by natural does not relax any of these constraints, it just means that trying to say anything meaningful becomes more difficult and prone to working error.

Start by defining natural or at the very least have a set of irreducible definitions to work within otherwise this may as well be pure speculation.

author: @Pestilencemage
text:
He's not wrong that laws are only made by the collective.  That is an odd way to say DEMOCRACY.  You can propose a law, but if it's not the will of the people, it is rejected ...ideally, if the system is just and good in a western liberty and freedom sense.

The person doing it alone would be anti-democratic.  It would be a law made in self-interest rather than the interests of the people and jurisdiction.  "Politics" is a giant debate about the definition of what is best in that regard.

replies.author: @Pestilencemage
replies.text:
Yes... anomalies.  Those that lost the election.  Their views are irrelevant.  Or, ideally, they did not represent the will of the people sufficiently to dictate this particular course of action in question, as another course of action has presented that represents a greater degree as the will of the people.

...exactly as democracy intended.

replies.author: @Pestilencemage
replies.text:
Yes, we are selfish.  This is absolutely unavoidable.  It can not be fixed.  ...it can be exploited.  It's effects can be mitigated.
We call this "capitalism".  The best method we've found.

The closest you can come to overcoming it is not to not be selfish, but to simply learn the benifits of cooperation, which quickly become self-evident without effort.  Then we learn how others are, and ourselves are... and it quickly becomes clear that we need to be trustworthy to benifit most.  **Trust is one of the axioms of value.**  without trust, there is no currency, no trade, and no cooperation.  You can the most efficient value from cooperation by having high trust levels between parties.  Think of your spouse, and I've proved my point I think.

So: I AM Trustworthy.  It's because it is to my benifit.  It's not my lack of greed, but a wise application of it.

It gets harder with freedom.  IF we all agree to libertarian principles of not harming others... yay.  Also greed.  I don't want to have gay orgies in my basement.  I DEMAND my right to do so.  I will not let them take away YOUR right to if I can help it.  ...I will regrettably let you remove your right to from yourself if it let's me keep my right to do it, though I'll advise you not to remove your right, and I still won't use my right I demanded.

It's the social contract.  "I won't block your freedoms if you don't block mine".  And we can for most issues.  But again we judge by the collective; we want max individual freedoms... but calculated as a mean of the total collective of individuals.  I can't have the freedom to rape because then we all lose the freedom to not be raped.  My individual freedom goes down.  Our individual freedoms go up.

Rationally stealing is fine as long as you don't get caught. It's a risk-reward system. Morally stealing is bad because we have an irrational right of ownership.

text:
when the British liberal philosophy advocates disagree with British liberal philosophy...
the German (Friedrich Karl von Savonie) was correct, by the standards of John Stuart Mill, as he states in "Utilitarianism", that what makes laws is first the impulse to make a law, which does and MUST come from the moral system of the society it comes from. This is definitely the same view as what you decried there.
the question is then: do you go against that hard enforcement of selected morals, or do you follow it?
from the views that Karl has been talking about, it clearls suggests, that you would like this followed, instead of the type of system you promoted here. 
please, get it straight.

author: @folechno
text: Josh says at the beginning that monkeys don‚Äôt understand property rights, and at the end that monkeys understand capitalism. These are contradictory, since property rights are part of the definition of capitalism, a society where everyone‚Äôs property rights are respected. The capuchin monkey experiment shows that they can understand abstract value and can set up a market, but does not show property rights. The black market for drugs that are illegal confirms it is possible to have a market devoid of protection for property rights. The capuchin monkey experiment is humorous, but often the legitimate conclusions are distorted to fit a world view. This is one instance. Also Marx is a horrible person with truly evil ideas. But that will show up in part 2.
